definition:
Let $R\subseteq E$ be a root system, with $E$ a Euclidean . If $R^+$ is
a set of positive roots, then a root is called [*simple*]{} if it is
positive, and not the sum of any two positive roots. The simple roots
form a basis of the vector space $E$, and any positive root is a
positive integer linear combination of simple roots.

A set of roots which is simple with respect to some choice of a set of
positive roots is called a [*base*]{}. The Weyl group of the root system
acts simply transitively on the set of bases.
